Posts.Title: Question about post-op/catheter and stairs

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Jake XYZ Thanks, Nick. I'm just imagining how not fun moving around with the catheter will be, but luckily this forum has put some of that fear to rest. Like I said, I have a couple surgeries before and both required a catheter,,,but only for 24 hours and I was laying in hospital bed during that time. But during that time, Mr. Johnson tried to get away by making himself as tiny as he could. He is a big baby...well a small baby...I am sure he is going to try to hide even more this time,, and I'm sure the staff will get a big laugh out of it. HA! I love it. I have a large catheter bag with a long hose for sleeping at night. Otherwise, the hospital provided a smaller bag that attaches to my leg with velcro straps. It's not bad at all and walking is no problem. If your hospital doesn't supply you with one, I would strongly recommend asking. I can't imagine having to deal with only having the larger bag. Nick

Posts.Content: I really didn't have much in the way of pain meds, but didn't really need them either. The first day, my abs were sore and I had bladder spasms. It felt like I needed to urinate but obviously that wasn't the case. My doc recommended an OTC urinary analgesic. I used AZO. It worked great. But, it caused a metallic taste in my mouth after the first 24 hours so I quit using it. Nick

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by DjinTonic I think you're best off with a full brief-type at the start. I used Mens Depends for a few weeks. Then I graduated down to high, moderate, and then light pads. Tried Tena, preferred Depends. Currently using one light pad/24 hr for a very slight, still improving, stress dribble. Don't worry if you have poor control the first couple of days after the cath is out Thanks, Djin. I was wondering the same thing. By the way, happy belated birthday. Nick

Posts.Title: Looking for excellent radiation oncology center in Orange County, CA

Posts.Content: Tom Although older than you (I'm 56), I'm still relatively young for PCa. I had my surgery 6 weeks ago today. I too am active and otherwise healthy. Although I did speak with a radiation oncologist, the decision for surgery was not a difficult one for me. There were three major factors. First, the effectiveness of treatments other than surgery are essentially compared to surgery. For me, I wanted to go with the treatment that was the measuring stick for the others. Second, if you go the radiation route, it's difficult or impossible to remove the prostate if cancer returns. Finally, I just felt like I wanted the cancer out of my body. My urological oncologist felt I would recover well from surgery given my age and health. It sounds like you will likely do the same. As Michael said, become as educated as you can. Guide to Surviving Prostate Cancer by Dr. Patrick Walsh is a fantastic book. It's recommended by many on this forum including me. Also, the side effects of the treatment options can vary and can impact your spouse or significant other. I strongly recommend discussing the issue with your partner. The decision is yours, of course. But, I believe it's very important to include loved ones in the discussion. My wife and I were totally on the same page with the decision for surgery. Six weeks post-op, I'm convinced I made the right call. Best of luck to you. Please keep us posted. Nick

Posts.Title: One Day Post-op

Posts.Content: The procedure went well. The doc said he spared both nerve bundles. That was unexpected considering he previously said he would take the right bundle. He feels pretty good that he got all the cancer, but we shall see when he discusses the path report at my follow up appointment in a week. I did have an issue during surgery. Coming out of anesthesia, they noticed my heart was not firing quite right. The called it a left branch bundle block. That apparent means that the electrical signals firing my heart were a bit out of sync. The did an EKG in recover and another EKG this morning. Both were normal. They also did an ultrasound on my heart and that was normal as well. I've never had any heart problems before. They now think it was just a reaction to the anesthesia so I was discharged today around 2:30 pm. I'm fairly sore but it's tolerable. I don't seem to have a lot of energy, but it's coming back. I suppose that's normal. Thanks for the support, guys! On to recovery. Nick

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Michael F Fortunately the bladder heals quickly, as does the urethra. Hopefully your URO Surgeon is not prognosticating unwanted outcomes. Did your URO Surgeon address the "EPEs at Right Apex" at time of surgery? Please ask him/her. Did he/she preoperativley plan an incision close to the bladder? In my non-medical professional opinion "PT3A" qualifies you for immediate post RP PSA monitoring by Ultrasensitive PSA (uPSA) monitoring moving forward starting at the 6 week post RP and then compared to the 12 week post RP level. Be sure to use the " Same Lab Using The Same uPSA Methodology" each time in order to compare results and make a Clinilcal assessment of your risk for recurrence status. For now, simply try to relax and focus on a optimizing a good recovery. Remain optimistic & simultaneously vigilant! Best wishes for a complete Cure! MF Hi Michael Great comments. Could you clarify what you mean by addressing the EPE at time of surgery? I'm not sure I'm following you on that. He did say that he tried to cut wide throughout the procedure. In my discussion with him yesterday, he said it was possible cauterization killed any cells that might have remained. In a pre-op discussion, he said he always strives for negative margins... although I imagine that would be the goal of any surgeon. Not sure if this addresses your comment. Regarding the uPSA monitoring at 6 and 12 weeks, I believe that to be the plan. He said he wanted to see PSA scores <=0.02. I assumed that was actually uPSA since I believe only uPSA is able to measure to that level. He did indeed pre-operatively plan an incision close to the bladder and said reconstruction may be a bit more of a challenge due to that incision farther up the bladder neck. I believe I'm doing a good job of being optimistic. If the follow up PSA scores are not ideal, I'll move on from there and take whatever steps are necessary to rid my body of this crap. I've got to admit that having this disease at a relatively young age is a bit scary (as if a CA diagnosis isn't scary enough at any age). The likelihood of BCR at some point along the path is disconcerting. But, I can't let myself dwell on that.

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Michael F Hi Nick! Apologies for the late response. I have both been away and missed your question. Some URO Surgeons will wait intraoperatively for an initial path report on surgical margins. If (+) they go back an excise additional tissues in the 'neighborhood' of the PMs. My only reason for suggesting uPSA monitoring is to detect a potentially rising PSA early. uPSA results are out to the 3rd decimal (and some beyond). Your URO Surgeon simply wants to see your post RP PSA at <0.02 which is 100% perfect. I do strongly advise getting original copies of each lab report. The exact Lab and exact PSA methodology will be listed on the report. Stay focussed on your recovery and forget about future PSAs! Getting rid of "The Foley" (a weird but painless sensation) will be make you feel like a new man! Keep optimistic at all times! MF Hi Michael For whatever reason, I didn't notice you replied. Sorry about that. My surgeon did not request intra-op pathology. I'm assuming he would have if the biopsy path report was worse. We never discussed this prior to the procedure so I'm guessing. Got rid of Foley yesterday and that has made a huge difference in my overall demeanor. As you said, I feel like a new man!

Posts.Content: Hi Jake I had RALP six weeks ago today. I was supposed to have my catheter removed one week post op. However, he detected that the bladder neck and urethra seal was not 100% so it stayed in another week. I was leaking badly for about two weeks. I was getting frustrated and concerned with my progress. With that said, I didn't have major problems with night leakage although I did have to get up often. At three weeks after catheter removal, leakage was greatly improved to the point that I graduated from diapers to shields. This past week has seen more good progress. The last few days, the shields have been just barely damp at the end of the day using only one shield per day. I'm sure everyone's experience is different. My advice would be to just relax. After the first couple weeks post-catheter, I started seeing noticeable progress every day. It'll come for you, too. Nick

Posts.Title: 15 day Post-RALP report

Posts.Content: Had my first follow up visit this morning. The doc said that he cut the bladder a bit close to the bladder to ensure he got all cancer cells in that area. So, the first order of business today was a cystogram image. It showed some very slight leakage at the connection. So, the doc wants to leave Mr. Foley in place until next week. Bummer. On to pathology. Prostate mass: 31g 25% involved Gleason mostly 3+4=7 Perineural invasion identified Extrprostatic extension at right apex Tumor at right base was at margin of resection (3.5mm across) Remainder of margins are negative Bladder neck, seminal vesicles, vas deferens, and lymph nodes (19) were all negative pT3a pN0 The current plan is to test PSA in 5 weeks (6 weeks post-op) and again in another 6 weeks. If PSA is below 0.02, the likely recommendation will be no additional treatment but need to monitor PSA. If the PSA is higher than 0.02, the likely recommendation will be radiation. My doctor said he's seen hundreds of path reports very similar to mine and says the probability is 60% of a PSA below 0.02. So, the news is a bit of a mixed bag. I'm continuing to be optimistic and looking forward to giving Mr. Foley the boot. Nick

Posts.Title: Two days post op

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by john4803 Keep it up, nixter, and protect little foley and try to see him as a temporary friend! Consider staying on stool softeners because any straining may tend to cause bladder spasms and urine to come out around him! Hopefully, your scrotum won't balloon up, like mine did, but it is normal. It makes for waddling vs. walking for a while. Keep looking forward! Thanks, John I've been taking a urinary analgesic which was recommended by my doctor. So far, minimal issues with bladder spasms. The stool softener looks to be good advice. I have some Milk of Magnesia which I believe I'll start taking. So far, no ballooning. Scrotum seems normal. I'm thinking that if I was going to have swelling, it would have happened by now. So far, so good.

Posts.Title: One Day Post-op

Posts.Content: The procedure went well. The doc said he spared both nerve bundles. That was unexpected considering he previously said he would take the right bundle. He feels pretty good that he got all the cancer, but we shall see when he discusses the path report at my follow up appointment in a week. I did have an issue during surgery. Coming out of anesthesia, they noticed my heart was not firing quite right. The called it a left branch bundle block. That apparent means that the electrical signals firing my heart were a bit out of sync. The did an EKG in recover and another EKG this morning. Both were normal. They also did an ultrasound on my heart and that was normal as well. I've never had any heart problems before. They now think it was just a reaction to the anesthesia so I was discharged today around 2:30 pm. I'm fairly sore but it's tolerable. I don't seem to have a lot of energy, but it's coming back. I suppose that's normal. Thanks for the support, guys! On to recovery. Nick

Posts.Title: 6 days RALP catheter out minimal leakage

Posts.Content: I bid a not so fond farewell to Mr. Foley yesterday. I'd say he was a pain in the ass, but that would not be entirely accurate. Foley was gone about 11:00 am. I was completely incontinent for the rest of the day. I put on a fresh Depends right before bed. I woke up expecting it to be saturated. But, it was just a bit damp. I then proceeded to urinate intentionally in the toilet. YAY!!! I can't recall the last time I was that happy to pee. With the exception of a few drips, I was able to go again intentionally a few hours later! I'm a long way from declaring I can hold my water. But, considering it is two weeks post-op, I'm hoping this indicates a strong probability of returning to complete continence. Nick

Posts.Title: Goodbye, Foley!

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by MichiganMan16 Nick: Do not make to many assumptions at this early stage in the game. It has only been a few weeks, and remember when u are lying down and sleeping, u are not dealing with gravity. All u can do for now is the kegel's, and start a walking routine to build up the muscles. It is way to early to worry about anything. Just take one day at a time, and measure your progress in weeks or weekly. BTW...was your G 4+3 downgraded to 3+4? If so, that is a big bonus for u. Stay strong and stay the course, MM Yeah. I'm trying not to be too excited about this. I realize this is going to be more of a journey rather than a sprint. I was just happy to intentionally hold the urine this morning until I was ready to release it. I didn't expect that. So far today, I'm able to hold in urine when sitting and walking around with a few drops escaping here and there. With that said, it's not like I'm doing jumping jacks. I'm working from home this week. But, I think I'm going to head over to the park for a little walk and see what happens. Good catch on the Gleason score, MM. The path report did show 3+4=7 so, yes. It was downgraded. I should add that to the signature. Nick

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by MichiganMan16 That's a downgrade that bodes very well for your future. And it's nice to see someone get a downgrade!! Congrats, and keep us posted on your progress. MM Originally Posted by DjinTonic For those interested, by coincidence, I added this study to the Subforum earlier today, Thread (D), #21 Incidence of metastasis and prostate-specific antigen levels at diagnosis in Gleason 3+4 versus 4+3 prostate cancer [2018] https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/29719335 (For Full Text, click on the DOI link at the bottom) Yeah. I'm all for getting as much good news as I can. Thanks, DT! Interesting read. It's been many years since I've had stats classes and I'm not completely up on all the medical jargon. However, I understand the main point of the article. 3+4 is significantly better than 4+3. Nick

Posts.Title: Goodbye, Foley!

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Michael F Congrats Nick! Glad that you are now fully liberated! Looks like you are a ahead of the "Continence Curve!" Follow MM16's suggestions. Be prepared to experience minor "squirts" with certain activities such as: - Involuntary: Sneezing, laughing, coughing - Voluntary: Getting out of car, jogging, jumping, doing sit ups. Be especially aware that ETOH consumption can open the floodgates! It is very important to "re-train" your bladder to fill to capacity. Avoid making frequent trips to urinate. Practice holding as long as possible to the point of discomfort. (Of course only do this when there is either a nearby toilet or bush!) Good luck on being "pad-free" fairly soon! It is always a good idea to keep a few pads on hand - just in case. Do the Kegel exercises according to your MDs advise. But do NOT overdo them as this can cause diminished results. Hope you can report "Sahara" status soon! MF Well, just took a 3 mile walk and I couldn't hold the water. I suppose that would have been a little too much to hope for. Michael, what would you consider 'overdoing' regarding the Kegels? Nick

Be especially aware that ETOH consumption can open the floodgates! It is very important to "re-train" your bladder to fill to capacity. Avoid making frequent trips to urinate. Practice holding as long as possible to the point of discomfort. (Of course only do this when there is either a nearby toilet or bush!) Good luck on being "pad-free" fairly soon! It is always a good idea to keep a few pads on hand - just in case. Do the Kegel exercises according to your MDs advise. But do NOT overdo them as this can cause diminished results. Hope you can report "Sahara" status soon! MF Well, just took a 3 mile walk and I couldn't hold the water. I suppose that would have been a little too much to hope for. Michael, what would you consider 'overdoing' regarding the Kegels? Nick

(2mm) Right Mid: 4+3=7. 60% pattern 4. 10% core involvement. (2mm) Right Mid: 3+3=6. <5% involvement. (0.5mm) Right Apex: 3+4=7. 10% pattern 4. 20% core involvement. (3mm) T1c Perineural invasion detected CT scan negative RALP 4/18/2018 Pathology: Prostate mass: 31g 25% involved Gleason mostly 3+4=7 Perineural invasion identified Extrprostatic extension at right apex Tumor at right base was at margin of resection (3.5mm across) Remainder of margins are negative Bladder neck, seminal vesicles, vas deferens, and lymph nodes (19) were all negative pT3a pN0 Post-op PSA 5/30/2018 - 0.01 Decipher Score - 0.79 High Risk 7/12/2018 - <0.01 undetectable 10/16/2018 - <0.01 undetectable 1/8/2019 - <0.008 undetectable
Posts.Title: Goodbye, Foley!

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by MichiganMan16 Nick: Do not make to many assumptions at this early stage in the game. It has only been a few weeks, and remember when u are lying down and sleeping, u are not dealing with gravity. All u can do for now is the kegel's, and start a walking routine to build up the muscles. It is way to early to worry about anything. Just take one day at a time, and measure your progress in weeks or weekly. BTW...was your G 4+3 downgraded to 3+4? If so, that is a big bonus for u. Stay strong and stay the course, MM Yeah. I'm trying not to be too excited about this. I realize this is going to be more of a journey rather than a sprint. I was just happy to intentionally hold the urine this morning until I was ready to release it. I didn't expect that. So far today, I'm able to hold in urine when sitting and walking around with a few drops escaping here and there. With that said, it's not like I'm doing jumping jacks. I'm working from home this week. But, I think I'm going to head over to the park for a little walk and see what happens. Good catch on the Gleason score, MM. The path report did show 3+4=7 so, yes. It was downgraded. I should add that to the signature. Nick

Posts.Title: Goodbye, Foley!

Posts.Content: I had my first post-op PSA test this morning which is exactly six weeks from RALP. My surgeon wanted to test 6 and 12 weeks out. I have not heard the news officially from him yet. However, his practice posts all information on their patient portal. I received an email notification that a test result had been posted. It's 0.01. Yahoo!!! I think I'll wait until the next test in 6 weeks before I officially declare myself a member of the Zero Club. But, this is certainly something to celebrate. This was a regular PSA test... not uPSA. Apparently, he's not a fan of uPSA per his nurse. He did a fellowship at Johns Hopkins. They don't seem to be fans of uPSA either, so that likely has influenced his opinion. Regardless, today has been a good day. Nick
